reviews.review_msg: The course was all-emcompassing including practical exercises to trace cybercrime activities, introduction to various theories and interesting readings. I appreciated the flexibility of the teacher given the remote teaching.

The course is easy, but Masarah is a little difficult to follow along with, as she reads off lecture slides quickly. The quizzes are easy, and I thought the midterm was easy too. The TA was genuinely bad though. Cicilia provided almost no feedback, and I had to get my final paper re-graded because apparently the TA thinks I'm a "60% range student."

CRIM 380 was fantastic with Masarah. The lectures were interesting with many easy, but very useful cyber tools to dig your hands into. Hands on practices were included in lectures, while quizzes are based upon them. They were easy to do, while actually helping you work with different parts of the cyberspace instead of dry lectures. Had a good time.

Quizzes were fairly easy and fun to do. The course content was interesting. She does not answer students' questions until the break or at the end of the lecture. She just reads off her slides and talks too fast. The questions in the exam are vague.
Worked by but off for the midterm and i did very well. Slacked it for the final and did okay. It is entirely up to the student to do well.
Took this class via distance. The online notes that she provides for her class are extremely helpful in preparation for the exam. Group presentation is relatively easy as well.
One of the best Crim profs at SFU. She is very passionate about the subject. I felt like I actually learned a lot about cyber crime. I recommend it.

She's an amazing prof who is passionate about cybercrime.  Go to lectures, read the textbook and do the discussion questions.  The midterm/final are fair; the essays are so general you can write down anything from the class as long as you provide examples from the class.

I attended majority of the classes. I followed the textbook and found out that you have to pay close attention to the teacher. I would recommend this course. Should be mandatory for any computer degree.
The course material is very good. I had to pay close attention or would fall behind. She knows her stuff, has written couple of books on the subject. This is not a slacker class.

The people who got low marks are slackers who never once raised their hands. I went to the classes, watched the videos, listened to the presentations and read the text. i got an A overall. Don't blame the prof because all you other guys did was not pay attention and just read the powerpoints the night before the exams.
This is the worst class I have ever taken in my entire life.  The prof was insultingly incompetent.  Condescending, and inaccurate to boot.

She is so catatonic. Plus half her class was failing the midterm and she did not want to change her answer key. Expects you to memorize rather than gain an understanding of the material. If you are willing to get a low B go right ahead. I would avoid this class and any other class taught by her.

So hopefully nobody else makes the same mistake that I did after reading some of the reviews. The class material is easy, but the way she marks the midterm and the final is quite unfair. Keep in mind my GPA is at a 3.8, and she pretty much screwed me over.The final essay was based on stuff we did not go over in lectures or readings. DO NOT TAKE 380

She just repeats what is in the textbook. She talks about the internet like is is 1996 and no one has any previously knowledge regarding it. She should watch a tape of her class and count all the people who are sleeping. At least 30% of students skip each class.

The average for the final was around the low forties (Not scaled). It was also cumulative and in-person (13 modules to remember!) The rubrics for the assignments weren't clear, so some people would submit 2 pages while others submitted 8 pages. I submitted 11 pages once but still received 7/10...

I am curious about Richard's role in this course because I just saw him once in the final. He had no office hours etc. and the tas were only responsible for the course. if you have a good ta, you are good. idk the course load appeared insane to me. i believe grading doesnt matter here but where exactly is our money going? to a course with tas?

Yikes. Workload=absolute insanity. Every week there was 100% something due. Whether it was an assignment or discussion post. You had to lead 2 discussions as well so some weeks more work ontop of all work due already. No midterm, assignments were meh but TAs is THE HARDEST marker (cicillia) run. Prof was MIA the whole term. dont take it trust me.

If you didn't enjoy Richard's class, it might be because you weren't fully engaged with the material. I took his CRIM480 course as well, and the resources he uses are well-chosen and relevant. Richard also provides feedback, and his TAs are always available to help if you reach out by email.

Very challenging class with time consuming assignments. No midterm. The final exam covered all course material. The average was 49%, so take this class only if you enjoy challenging exams and make sure you do really good on the assignments and tutorial presentation to boost your grade.

if you're looking for a gpa booster, this is not it, idc who said it was, it is not. the final was extremely brutal, i thought they'd scale, but no, brought my otherwise academic comeback gpa down brutally. weekly assignments were ok, the grading was what was upsetting, you could be doing everything right and here comes a 7/10
Damn why the TA mark so hard
why the prof kinda...

The professor was nice but the class was really difficult. The assignments took considerable amounts of time without clear directions on how to complete them. Many assignments listed a website to use and "screenshot" our answers but did not explain how to use these websites which were hard to navigate??? overall not a easy course or gpa booster

He's a lovely and caring prof that has a wide array of knowledge.He is very active as a prof in an online class.However,this class was extremely hard.Assignments were only worth 6% and take a considerable amount of time,marked very hard, and TAs don't give good feedback.Exam is extremely hard the average was 55%, he did say he would scale the marks

If your looking for an easy gps booster, this is not the class. Assignments require significant work and the exam  is challenging. This class is interesting and will provide you with all the critical/ fundamental cyber concepts. If you have any interest in a cyber career,  Professor Franks knowledge and course material surpasses expectations.

Great class, the content is so interesting! There are 8 assignments that can be time-intensive but totally manageable. The final can be daunting since it is cumulative but was fair and very straightforward if you study. No obscure questions on random facts.

Dr. Frank gives amazing lectures and is very approachable for extra help. 

10/10 class

The lectures were interesting for the most part. Weekly assignments (choose 8 of your choice) were straightforward but time-consuming. Tutorial participation and one presentation were also required. No midterm. Lots of additional readings to familiarize yourself more with the content. Final exam was pretty overwhelming but is doable if you study.

Dr Frank is a very nice prof. He tries his best to make classes interesting and the course itself is pretty insightful. However, if your looking for a easier class this is not it. The class consists of weekly assignments which are mostly 4 page papers and usually do not help whatsoever in the weeks topic. The final is BRUTAL.

The content was very interesting and valuable information. Only issues were that the weekly assignments were very time consuming (5 papers, 4 pages each, plus other assignments only worth 2% each). Too many weekly readings; final exam covers too much info and you do not have enough time to finish; each section is timed so you don't have enough time

I took this class online and found it easy to navigate, however, final exam was tricky. There is no midterm, so the final includes 13 weeks of content. There are way too many readings and videos assigned each week, you have to keep up because of discussions and weekly assignments based on the readings. For the final, just memorize everything :)

Very chill and easy class with Dr Frank, however you do not expect the final examination to be as difficult as it was. Majority of the class was walking in with over 90 and dropped by at least ten percent after the exam. Be prepared and do the readings.

Took this through distance ed with TM Ryan. This course was awesome. TM was great; answered questions in a timely manner. While there were weekly assignments, they didn't take long to complete and if you didn't get perfect marks, the TM would have left you feedback on how to improve for next time.

One of SFU's most chill profs out there. Easy-going personality, informative lectures, good connection to make if you want to go into cybercrime studies. Super easy class, four small papers plus tests and tutorial participation are all doable, nothing crazy. He's passionate about his stuff so don't feel afraid to ask him questions during class!

Richard is very knowledgable and funny. Material was interesting and relevant. Grade breakdown is a bit ridiculous.. 5 thought papers (all 2-3 pages) are only worth 2% each. Pretty heavy workload for what everything is worth and the amount of time put in

Richard is great, he is extremely knowledgable about what he teaches and what he has accomplished career-wise is inspirational. His assignments are actually fun, and I like that he tries to get to know his students. Fast marker and responds to emails quickly. Lots of readings and a lot of work required, so get ready to read.

Great teacher overall. You can tell from his lectures that he is truly passionate about computers and technology. He does not treat people like idiots even though his knowledge is far and beyond the typical student. Course material is mindblowingly interesting. All lecture ntoes/slides are posted online as well so if you miss something, don't worry

One of the more interesting CRIM classes to take at SFU. Most of the questions on his exams come straight from his powerpoint slides but there may be a couple questions that might surprise you. You have to do 2 presentations in tutorial but you will most likely have a partner.
A lot of time required for CRIM 380. Not necessarily very difficult, just very time consuming.

I really enjoyed the class. As long as you do the work and study well, you can do quite well. The thought papers were marked well, participating also helps you get a good grade. Overall, this is a great course and will make you want to take the next level.

Richard will impart on you an appreciation for the complexity of cybercrime and the challenges facing law enforcement and private companies protecting their data. This course will stimulate your thinking so get ready to learn lots and come away with your money well spent!

Lectures cite the most current data; incorporates recent events into class discussion and genuinely wants to see students do well. Be prepared to look at cybercrime in int' & multidisciplinary lens. Be prepared to write 2-3 pages per week and do 2 presentations. Invaluable insight gained + possible career option!

Although his lectures are a bit dry, Frank is pretty fair with his expectations. His exams are on par with his lecture notes but there will be a couple surprises on the exam which comes from his lectures. So if you attend his classes and keep up with the material I can not see why you can't end with a decent grade
Boring class, readings were useless and his jokes are lame. Exams are all short answers. Memorize his slides inside out and you'll do ok.

Test questions are very convoluted, almost treats the class as a secondary hobby to his research. Only does tests in one format (short answer) because he "doesn't know how" to do other formats ie. multiple choice. Does not know answers to many questions asked during lecture. (I'm not sure, I don't know, etc.) Boring, TA marks extremely unfair/hard.
Spends too much time on research and does not remark test where the TA clearly made many mistakes.

Had Andrew a few semesters ago and he's a fantastic TA. Anyone who complains about him obviously just didn't try very hard in the class---it's not his fault how the prof asks him to grade things! It's true that he's ridiculously attractive, but aside from that, he's smart, helpful, and explains things well. He's going to make a fantastic prof.
AMAZING TA! I hope he TAs other courses in the future. Clear, fair but tough marker, and nice to look at, too.

He knows his material  and teaches well.  There is only so much a TA can do when there is no one that responds to conversation about topics in tutorial.  He does mark difficult but that is part of the job.  This is university not community college first come first in program. Rather will not comment on looks.

Does not mark hard, but rather unfairly. Not open to having marks disputed. Can't believe the prof let him mark the mid-term, presentations etc. among other things. Seems like he's just marking hard to prove something to the prof. about his "strictness." Let's hope he doesn't expand past his TA role and actually teach other classes.
